revision.text:
[[File:Grooming monkeys PLW edit.jpg|thumb|300px|An adult [[olive baboon]] grooms a juvenile]] [[File:Animal Communication.jpg|alt=A Cat Communicating through social grooming.|thumb|A cat socially grooming.]] '''Social grooming''' is a behaviour in which [[social animal]]s, including [[human]]s, clean or maintain one another's body or appearance. A related term, '''allogrooming''', indicates social grooming between members of the same species. Grooming is a major social activity, and a means by which animals who live in close proximity may [[Psychological bond|bond]] and reinforce social structures, family links, and build companionships. Social grooming is also used as a means of [[conflict resolution]], maternal behaviour and [[Reconciliation ecology|reconciliation]] in some species.<ref name="Henazi"/><ref name="van Schaik"/> '''Mutual grooming''' typically describes the act of grooming between two individuals, often as a part of social grooming, [[pair bonding]], or a [[Foreplay|precoital activity]].
== Evolutionary advantages == There are a variety of proposed mechanisms by which social grooming behavior has been hypothesized to increase [[Fitness (biology)|fitness]]. These evolutionary advantages may come in the form of health benefits including reduced [[Transmission (medicine)|disease transmission]] and reduced stress levels, maintaining social structure, and direct improvement of fitness as a measure of survival.
=== Health benefits === Social grooming behavior has been shown to elicit an array of health benefits in a variety of species.  For example, group member connection has the potential to mitigate the potentially harmful effects of [[stressor]]s. In [[macaque]]s, social grooming has been proven to reduce [[heart rate]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MNBefb0j-ksC&pg=PA199&dq=the+role+of+emotion+in+conflict+and+conflict+resolution#v=onepage&q=the%20role%20of%20emotion%20in%20conflict%20and%20conflict%20resolution&f=false|title=Natural Conflict Resolution|last=Aureli|first=Filippo|last2=Waal|first2=Frans B. M.|date=2000-01-01|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520223462|location=|pages=193–224|language=en}}</ref> Social affiliation during a mild stressor was shown to correlate with lower levels of mammary tumor development and longer lifespan in rats, while lack of this affiliation was demonstrated to be a major risk factor.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yee|first=Jason R.|last2=Cavigelli|first2=Sonia A.|last3=Delgado|first3=Bertha|last4=McClintock|first4=Martha K.|title=Reciprocal Affiliation Among Adolescent Rats During a Mild Group Stressor Predicts Mammary Tumors and Lifespan|url=http://content.wkhealth.com/linkback/openurl?sid=WKPTLP:landingpage&an=00006842-200811000-00013|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|volume=70|issue=9|pages=1050–1059|doi=10.1097/psy.0b013e31818425fb|pmid=18842748|pmc=5767077|year=2008}}</ref> Grooming has also been shown to play an integral role in reducing tick load in wild baboons (''[[Yellow baboon|Papio cynocephalus]]''). These ectoparasitic ticks carry the potential to act as [[vector (epidemiology)|vector]]s for the spreading of [[disease]] and [[infection]] by common tick-borne [[Parasitism|parasites]] such as [[Protozoa|haemoprotozoan]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Akinyi|first=Mercy Y.|last2=Tung|first2=Jenny|last3=Jeneby|first3=Maamun|last4=Patel|first4=Nilesh B.|last5=Altmann|first5=Jeanne|last6=Alberts|first6=Susan C.|date=2013-03-01|title=Role of grooming in reducing tick load in wild baboons (Papio cynocephalus)|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347212005611|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=85|issue=3|pages=559–568|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2012.12.012|pmc=3961061|pmid=24659824|via=}}</ref> Baboons with lower tick loads show decreased occurrence of such infections and display signs of greater health status, evidenced by higher [[hematocrit]] (packed red cell volume) levels.
=== Reinforcing social structure and building relationships === One of the most critical functions of social grooming is to establish social networks and relationships. In many species, individuals form close social connections dubbed “friendships.”<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Seyfarth|first=Robert M.|last2=Cheney|first2=Dorothy L.|date=July 5, 2011|title=The Evolutionary Origins of Friendship|url=http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/10.1146/annurev.soc.34.040507.134601|journal=Annual Review of Psychology|volume=63|pages=153–177|doi=10.1146/annurev-psych-120710-100337|pmid=21740224}}</ref> In primates especially, grooming is known to have major social significance and function in the formation and maintenance of these friendships.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schino|first=Gabriele|date=2001-08-01|title=Grooming, competition and social rank among female primates: a meta-analysis|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347201917506|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=62|issue=2|pages=265–271|doi=10.1006/anbe.2001.1750}}</ref> Grooming networks in [[black crested gibbon]]s have been proven to contribute greater social cohesion and stability.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guan|first=Zhen-Hua|last2=Huang|first2=Bei|last3=Ning|first3=Wen-He|last4=Ni|first4=Qing-Yong|last5=Sun|first5=Guo-Zheng|last6=Jiang|first6=Xue-Long|date=2013-12-01|title=Significance of grooming behavior in two polygynous groups of western black crested gibbons: Implications for understanding social relationships among immigrant and resident group members|journal=American Journal of Primatology|language=en|volume=75|issue=12|pages=1165–1173|doi=10.1002/ajp.22178|pmid=23843246|issn=1098-2345}}</ref> Groups of gibbons with more stable social networks formed grooming networks that were significantly more complex, while groups with low stability networks formed far fewer grooming pairs. In [[meerkat]]s, social grooming has been shown to carry the role of maintaining relationships that increase [[fitness (biology)|fitness]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kutsukake|first=Nobuyuki|last2=Clutton-Brock|first2=Tim H.|date=2010-02-01|title=Grooming and the value of social relationships in cooperatively breeding meerkats|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347209004655|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=79|issue=2|pages=271–279|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2009.10.014}}</ref> In this system, researchers have observed that dominant males receive more grooming while grooming others less, thereby indicating that less dominant males groom more dominant individuals to maintain relationships. In addition to primates, animals such as deer, cows, horses, vole, mice, meerkats, coati, lions, birds, bats also form social bonds through grooming behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carter|first=Gerald|last2=Leffer|first2=Lauren|date=2015-10-07|title=Social Grooming in Bats: Are Vampire Bats Exceptional?|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=10|issue=10|pages=e0138430|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0138430|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4596566|pmid=26445502}}</ref> Social grooming is critical for vampire bats especially, since it is necessary for them to maintain food-sharing relationships in order to sustain their food regurgitation sharing behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carter|first=Gerald|last2=Leffer|first2=Lauren|date=2015-10-07|title=Social Grooming in Bats: Are Vampire Bats Exceptional?|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=10|issue=10|pages=e0138430|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0138430|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4596566|pmid=26445502}}</ref>
=== Direct fitness consequences === Social grooming relationships have been proven to provide direct fitness benefits to a variety of species. In particular, grooming in [[yellow baboon]]s (''Papio cynocephalus'') has been studied extensively, with numerous studies showing an increase in fitness as a result of social bonds formed through social grooming behavior. One such study, which collected 16 years of behavioral data on wild baboons, highlights the effects that [[sociality]] has on infant survival.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Silk|first=Joan B.|last2=Alberts|first2=Susan C.|last3=Altmann|first3=Jeanne|date=2003-11-14|title=Social Bonds of Female Baboons Enhance Infant Survival|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/302/5648/1231|journal=Science|language=en|volume=302|issue=5648|pages=1231–1234|doi=10.1126/science.1088580|issn=0036-8075|pmid=14615543}}</ref> A positive relationship is established between infant survival to one year and a composite sociality index, a measure of sociality based on proximity and social grooming. Evidence has also been provided for the effect of sociality on adult survival in wild baboons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Archie|first=Elizabeth A.|last2=Tung|first2=Jenny|last3=Clark|first3=Michael|last4=Altmann|first4=Jeanne|last5=Alberts|first5=Susan C.|date=2014-10-22|title=Social affiliation matters: both same-sex and opposite-sex relationships predict survival in wild female baboons|url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/281/1793/20141261|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|language=en|volume=281|issue=1793|pages=20141261|doi=10.1098/rspb.2014.1261|issn=0962-8452|pmc=4173677|pmid=25209936|via=}}</ref> Direct correlations between measures of social connectedness (which focuses on social grooming) and median survival time for both female and male baboons were modeled. [[File:DataFigure1.png|left|thumb|300x300px|The relationship between median survival time and social connectedness in female baboons<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Archie|first=Elizabeth A.|last2=Tung|first2=Jenny|last3=Clark|first3=Michael|last4=Altmann|first4=Jeanne|last5=Alberts|first5=Susan C.|date=2014-10-22|title=Social affiliation matters: both same-sex and opposite-sex relationships predict survival in wild female baboons|url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/281/1793/20141261|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|language=en|volume=281|issue=1793|pages=20141261|doi=10.1098/rspb.2014.1261|issn=0962-8452|pmc=4173677|pmid=25209936}}</ref>]]
Social bonds established by grooming may provide an adaptive advantage in the form of conflict resolution and protection from aggression. In wild savannah baboons, social affiliations are shown to augment fitness by increasing tolerance from more dominant group members <ref name="Henazi">{{Cite journal|last=Henazi|first=Peter S.|last2=Barrett|first2=Louise|date=1999-01-01|title=The value of grooming to female primates|journal=Primates|language=en|volume=40|issue=1|pages=47–59|doi=10.1007/BF02557701|pmid=23179531|issn=0032-8332}}</ref> and increasing the chance of obtaining aid from [[conspecifics]] during instances of within-group contest interactions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sterck|first=Elisabeth H. M.|last2=Watts|first2=David P.|last3=Schaik|first3=Carel P. van|date=1997-11-01|title=The evolution of female social relationships in nonhuman primates|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|language=en|volume=41|issue=5|pages=291–309|doi=10.1007/s002650050390|issn=0340-5443|hdl=1874/1183}}</ref> In the yellow baboon, adult females form relationships with their kin, who offer support during times of violent conflict within social groups.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Silk|first=Joan B|last2=Alberts|first2=Susan C|last3=Altmann|first3=Jeanne|date=2004-03-01|title=Patterns of coalition formation by adult female baboons in Amboseli, Kenya|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347203003634|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=67|issue=3|pages=573–582|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2003.07.001}}</ref> In [[Barbary macaque]]s'','' social grooming results in the formation of crucial relationships among partners. These social relationships serve to aid cooperation and facilitate protection against combative groups composed of other males, which can oftentimes cause physical harm.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berghänel|first=Andreas|last2=Ostner|first2=Julia|last3=Schröder|first3=Uta|last4=Schülke|first4=Oliver|title=Social bonds predict future cooperation in male Barbary macaques, Macaca sylvanus|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=81|issue=6|pages=1109–1116|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2011.02.009|year=2011}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Furthermore, social relationships have also been proven to decrease risk of infanticide in several primates.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schaik|first=Carel P. Van|last2=Kappeler|first2=Peter M.|date=1997-11-22|title=Infanticide risk and the evolution of male–female association in primates|url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/264/1388/1687|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|language=en|volume=264|issue=1388|pages=1687–1694|doi=10.1098/rspb.1997.0234|issn=0962-8452|pmc=1688726|pmid=9404030|via=}}</ref>
== Altruism == [[Altruism (biology)|Altruism]], in the biological sense, refers to a behavior performed by an individual that increases the [[Fitness (biology)|fitness]] of another individual while decreasing the fitness of the one performing the behavior.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Selection : the mechanism of evolution|last=Graham.|first=Bell|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0198569725|oclc=781154368}}</ref> This differs from the philosophical concept of [[altruism]] which requires the conscious intention of helping another. As a behavior, altruism is not evaluated in moral terms, but rather as a consequence of an action for [[reproductive fitness]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2013/entries/altruism-biological/|title=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|last=Okasha|first=Samir|date=2013-01-01|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Fall 2013}}</ref> It is often questioned why the behavior persists if it is costly to the one performing it, however, [[Charles Darwin]] proposed [[group selection]] as the mechanism behind the clear advantages of altruism.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Descent of Man, and Selection in Relation to Sex.|year=1871|publisher=John Murray|last=Darwin|first=Charles|language=en|doi=10.5962/bhl.title.2092|hdl = 2027/bc.ark:/13960/t96696g2b}}</ref>
Social grooming is considered a behavior of facultative altruism- the behavior itself is a temporary loss of direct fitness (with potential for indirect fitness gain), followed by personal reproduction.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Trivers|first=Robert L.|date=1971-03-01|title=The Evolution of Reciprocal Altruism|journal=The Quarterly Review of Biology|volume=46|issue=1|pages=35–57|doi=10.1086/406755|issn=0033-5770}}</ref> This tradeoff has been compared to the [[Prisoner's dilemma|Prisoner's Dilemma]] model, and out of this comparison came [[Robert Trivers]] reciprocal altruism theory under the title "tit-for-tat".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Axelrod|first=R.|last2=Hamilton|first2=W. D.|date=1981-03-27|title=The evolution of cooperation|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/211/4489/1390|journal=Science|language=en|volume=211|issue=4489|pages=1390–1396|doi=10.1126/science.7466396|issn=0036-8075|pmid=7466396}}</ref> In conjunction with altruism, [[kin selection]] bears an emphasis on favoring the reproductive success of an organism's relatives, even at a cost to the organism's own survival and reproduction.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.classicreader.com/book/107/59/|title=Origin of Species : Chapter VIII. Instinct : Objections to the theory of natural selection as applied to instincts: neuter and sterile insects by Charles Darwin @ Classic Reader|website=www.classicreader.com|access-date=2017-03-23}}</ref> Because of this, kin selection is an instance of [[inclusive fitness]], which combines the number of offspring produced with the number an individual can ensure the production of by supporting others, such as siblings.
=== Hamilton's Rule === <math>rB>C</math>
Developed by [[W. D. Hamilton|W.D. Hamilton]], this rule governs the idea that kin selection causes genes to increase in frequency when the genetic relatedness (r) of a recipient to an actor multiplied by the benefit to the recipient (B) is greater than the reproductive cost to the actor (C).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wright|first=Sewall|date=1922-07-01|title=Coefficients of Inbreeding and Relationship|journal=The American Naturalist|volume=56|issue=645|pages=330–338|doi=10.1086/279872|issn=0003-0147}}</ref> Thus, it is advantageous for an individual to partake in altruistic behaviors, such as social grooming, so long as the individual receiving the benefits of the behavior is related to the one providing the behavior.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Evolutionary genetics|last=)|first=Smith, John Maynard, (1920-|date=1996-01-01|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0198542155|oclc=954574132}}</ref>
=== Use as a commodity === It was questioned whether some animals are instead using altruistic behaviors as a market strategy to trade for something desirable. In olive baboons, ''[[Olive baboon|Papio anubis]],'' it has been found that individuals perform altruistic behaviors as a form of trade in which a behavior is provided in exchange for benefits, such as [[Aggression|reduced aggression]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Frank|first=Rebecca|year=January 2009|title=Impatient traders or contingent reciprocators? Evidence for the extended time-course of grooming exchanges in baboons|url=http://www.sscnet.ucla.edu/anthro/faculty/silk/PDF%20Files%20Pubs/Frank%20&%20Silk%202009%20Grooming.pdf|journal=Behavior|volume=146|issue=8|pages=1123–1135|via=Brill|doi=10.1163/156853909x406455}}</ref> The grooming was evenly balanced across multiple bouts rather than single bouts, suggesting that females are not constrained to complete exchanges with single transactions and use social grooming to solidify long term relationships with those in their [[social group]].<ref name=":0" />
In addition, [[Lar gibbon|white-handed gibbons]] (''Hylobates lar)'' confirmed that males were more attentive to social grooming during [[Estrous cycle|estrus]] of the females in their group.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Barelli|first=Claudia|last2=Reichard|first2=Ulrich H.|last3=Mundry|first3=Roger|date=2011-10-01|title=Is grooming used as a commodity in wild white-handed gibbons, Hylobates lar?|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347211002922|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=82|issue=4|pages=801–809|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2011.07.012}}</ref> Though the behavior of social grooming itself was not beneficial to the one providing the service, the opportunity to mate and subsequent [[Fertilisation|fertilization]] increases the [[reproductive fitness]] of those participating in the behavior. This study was also successful in finding that social grooming performance cycled with that of the females [[Menstrual cycle|ovarian cycle]].<ref name=":1" />
==Mutual grooming== <gallery mode="nolines"> File:Mutually grooming ponies new forest.jpg|Mutual grooming in [[Pony|ponies]] File:Indian Macaques grooming.jpg|Three [[macaque]]s grooming one another File:Anodorhynchus hyacinthinus - New Orleans 2.jpg|Social grooming in [[hyacinth macaw]]s File:Preening budgerigars (Melopsittacus undulatus).webm | Female [[budgerigar]] preening the male (video) File:Social grooming lions.ogv|One [[lion]] grooming another File:Yb Babbler DSC 7018.jpg|Allopreening in [[Yellow-billed Babbler]] File:Bonnet macaque DSC 0982.jpg|[[Bonnet macaque]] allogrooming while infant suckles </gallery>
Many [[social animal|animal]]s groom each other in the form of stroking, scratching, and massaging. This activity often serves to remove foreign material from the body to promote the communal success of these socially active animals. There exists a wide array of socially grooming animals throughout the kingdom, including primates, insects,<ref name="Moore1995">{{citation|title=A highly specialized social grooming honey bee(Hymenoptera: Apidae)|year=1995|last1=Moore|last2=Angel|last3=Cheeseman|last4=Robinson|last5=Fahrbach|first1=D.|first2=J.E.|first3=I.M.|first4=G.E.|first5=S.E.|journal=Journal of Insect Behavior|volume=8|issue=6|pages=855–861|doi=10.1007/BF02009512}}</ref> birds,<ref name="Spruijt1992">{{citation|title=Ethology and neurobiology of grooming behavior|year=1992|last1=Spruijt|last2=Van Hooff|last3=Gispen|first1=B.M.|first2=J.A.|first3=W.H.|journal=Physiological Reviews|volume=72|issue=3|pages=825–852|pmid=1320764|doi=10.1152/physrev.1992.72.3.825|hdl=1874/3750}}</ref> and bats.<ref name="Wilkinson1986">{{citation|last=Wilkinson|first=G.S.|title=Social grooming in the common vampire bat, ''Desmodus rotundus''|url=http://www.life.umd.edu/faculty/wilkinson/Wilk_AB86.pdf|year=1986|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=34|issue=6|pages=1880–1889|doi=10.1016/S0003-3472(86)80274-3|citeseerx=10.1.1.539.5104}}</ref> While thorough research has still yet to be engaged, much has been learned about social grooming in non-human animals via the study of primates. The driving force behind mammal social grooming is primarily believed to be rooted in adaptation to [[Consolation|consolatory behavior]] as well as [[Utilitarianism|utilitarian]] purposes in the exchange of resources such as food, sex, and communal hygiene.<ref name="van Schaik">{{cite journal|last2=van Schaik|first2=C.|last3=van Hooff|first3=J|year=1989|title=Functional aspects of reconciliation among captive long-tailed macaques (''Macaca fascicularis'')|url=|journal=[[American Journal of Primatology]]|volume=19|issue=|pages=39–51|doi=10.1002/ajp.1350190105|last1=Aureli|first1=F.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|year=1968|title=The behavior of free living chimpanzees in the Gombe Stream Reserve|url=|journal=Animal Behaviour Monographs|volume=1|issue=|pages=161–311|doi=10.1016/s0066-1856(68)80003-2|last1=Lawick-Goodall|first1=J. van}}</ref><ref>de Waal, F. (1989). Peacemaking among primates. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press.</ref><ref>[[Barbara Smuts|Smuts, B.]], Cheney, D., Seyfarth, R., [[Richard Wrangham|Wrangham, R.]], & Struhsaker, T. (1987). Primate Societies. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.</ref>[[File:Honey Bee Grooming.png|thumb]]
=== Insects === In insects, grooming often involves the important role of removing foreign material from the body. The honey bee, for example, engages in social grooming by cleaning body parts that cannot be reached by the receiving bee. The receiving bee extends their wings perpendicular to their body while their wings, mouth parts, and antennae are cleaned in order to remove dust and pollen. This removal of dust and pollen allows for sharpening of olfactory senses in contributing to the overall well being of the group.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Moore | first1 = D. | last2 = Angel | first2 = J. E. | last3 = Cheeseman | first3 = I. M. | last4 = Robinson | first4 = G. E. | last5 = Fahrbach | first5 = S. E. | year = 1995 | title = A highly specialized social grooming honey bee (Hymenoptera: Apidae) | url = | journal = Journal of Insect Behavior | volume = 8 | issue = 6| pages = 855–861 | doi = 10.1007/BF02009512 }}</ref>
=== Bats === Recent studies have determined that vampire bats engage in social grooming much more than other types of bats to promote the well-being of the group. Facing higher levels of parasitic infection, vampire bats engage in cleaning one another as well as sharing food via regurgitation. This activity prevents ongoing infection while also promoting group success.<ref>Carter G.; Leffer L. (2015), Social Grooming in Bats: Are Vampire Bats Exceptional?. ''PLOS ONE'' 10(10): e0138430. <nowiki>https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0138430</nowiki></ref>
=== Primates === [[File:Vampire bat allogrooming.jpg|thumb]] Primates provide perhaps one of the best example of mutual grooming due to the intensive research performed regarding their varying lifestyles, and the direct variation of means of social grooming across different species. Among primates, social grooming plays a significant role in animal [[consolation]] behavior whereby the primates engage in establishing and maintaining alliances through [[dominance hierarchy|dominance hierarchies]], pre-existing coalitions, and for reconciliation after conflicts. Primates groom socially in moments of boredom as well, and the act has been shown to reduce tension and stress.<ref name="Schino1988">{{citation|title=Allogrooming as a tension-reduction mechanism: a behavioral approach|year=1988|last1=Schino|last2=Scucchi|last3=Maestripieri|last4=Turillazzi|first1=G.|first2=S.|first3=D.|first4=P.G.|journal=American Journal of Primatology|volume=16|pages=43–50|doi=10.1002/ajp.1350160106}}</ref> This reduction in stress is often associated with observed periods of relaxed behavior, and primates have been known to fall asleep while receiving grooming.<ref name="Smuts1985">{{citation|title=Sex and Friendship in Baboons|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vx_l76muFWMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=smuts+%22Sex+and+Friendship+in+Baboons%22&q|year=1985|author=Smuts, Barbara|place=New York|publisher=Aldine Publications|isbn=978-0-202-02027-3|accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref>
Grooming in primates is not only utilized for alliance formation and maintenance, but to exchange resources such as communal food, sex, and hygiene. Wild baboons have been found to utilize social grooming as an activity to remove ticks and other insects from others. In this grooming, the body areas receiving significant attention appear to be the regions where the baboons themselves cannot reach. Grooming activity in these regions is used to remove parasites, dirt, dead skin, as well as tangled fur to help keep the animal’s health in good condition despite an individual inability to reach and clean certain areas.<ref>Smuts, Barbara B. ''Sex & friendship in baboons''. New Brunswick: Aldine Transaction, 2009. Print.</ref>
Recent studies regarding chimpanzees have determined the direct correlation of the release of oxytocin to consolatory behavior.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lawick-Goodall | first1 = J. van | year = 1968 | title = The behavior of free living chimpanzees in the Gombe Stream Reserve | url = | journal = Animal Behaviour Monographs | volume = 1 | issue = | pages = 161–311 | doi = 10.1016/s0066-1856(68)80003-2 }}</ref> This behavior as well as release has been noted in primates such as the Vervet monkey, a primate species that actively engages in social grooming from early childhood to adulthood. [[Vervet monkey]] siblings often have conflict over grooming allocation by their mother, yet, grooming remains an activity that mediates tension and is low cost for alliance formation and maintenance. This grooming occurs both between the siblings as well as involving the mother.<ref>de Waal, F. (1989). Peacemaking among primates. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press</ref>
Recent studies regarding the [[crab-eating macaque]]s have shown that males will groom females in order to procure sex. One study found that a female has a greater likelihood to engage in sexual activity with a male if he had recently groomed her, compared to males who had not groomed her.[[Social grooming#cite note-41|<sup>[41]</sup>]]
=== Birds === {{Main|Preening (bird)#Allopreening}} In 2010, researchers determined the existence of a form of social grooming as a consolation behavior within ravens via a form of bystander contact, whereby observer ravens would act to console a distressed victim via contact sitting, preening, as well as beak-to-beak touching.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Orlaith | first1 = N.F. | last2 = Bugnyar | first2 = T. | year = 2010 | title = Do Ravens Show Consolation? Responses to Distressed Others | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 5| issue = 5| page = e10605| doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0010605 | pmid = 20485685 | pmc=2868892}}</ref>
=== Horses === Horses engage in mutual grooming via the formation of [[Pair bond|'pair bonds]]' where parasites and other contaminants on the surface of the body are actively removed. This removal of foreign material is primarily performed in hard-to-reach areas such as the neck via nibbling.<ref>Feh, C., De Mazieres, J. Grooming at a preferred site reduces heart rate in horses. Anim. Behav. 1993;46:1191–1194.</ref>
===Cattle=== Allogrooming is a behaviour commonly seen in many types of cattle, including dairy and beef breeds. The act of social licking can be seen specifically in heifers to initiate social dominance, emphasize companionship and improve hygiene of oneself or others. This behaviour seen in cows may provide advantages including reduced parasite loads, social tension and competition at the feed bunk.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Val-Laillet|first=David|last2=Guesdon|first2=Vanessa|last3=Keyserlingk|first3=Marina A.G. von|last4=Passillé|first4=Anne Marie de|last5=Rushen|first5=Jeffrey|title=Allogrooming in cattle: Relationships between social preferences, feeding displacements and social dominance|journal=Applied Animal Behaviour Science|volume=116|issue=2–4|pages=141–149|doi=10.1016/j.applanim.2008.08.005|year=2009}}</ref> It is understood that social licking can provide long term benefits such as promoting positive emotions and a relaxed environment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Laister|first=Simone|last2=Stockinger|first2=Barbara|last3=Regner|first3=Anna-Maria|last4=Zenger|first4=Karin|last5=Knierim|first5=Ute|last6=Winckler|first6=Christoph|title=Social licking in dairy cattle—Effects on heart rate in performers and receivers|journal=Applied Animal Behaviour Science|volume=130|issue=3–4|pages=81–90|doi=10.1016/j.applanim.2010.12.003|year=2011}}</ref>
==Endocrine effects== Social grooming has shown to be correlated with changes in endocrine levels within individuals. Specifically, there is a large correlation between the brain's release of oxytocin and social grooming. Oxytocin is hypothesized to promote prosocial behaviours due to its positive emotional response when released.<ref name=":2" /> Further, social grooming also releases beta-endorphins which promote physiological responses in stress reduction. These responses can occur from the production of hormones and endorphins, or through the growth or reduction in nerve structures. For example, in studies of suckling rats, rats who received warmth and touch when feeding had lower blood pressure levels than rats who did not receive any touch. This was found to be a result of an increased vagal nerve tone, meaning they had had higher parasympathetic nervous response and lower sympathetic nervous response to stimulus, resulting in a lower stress response.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306453098000560|title=OXYTOCIN MAY MEDIATE THE BENEFITS OF POSITIVE SOCIAL INTERACTION AND EMOTIONS|access-date=2017-03-24 | doi=10.1016/S0306-4530(98)00056-0|volume=23|issue=8|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|pages=819–835|date=November 1998|last1=Uvnäs-Moberg|first1=Kerstin}}</ref> Social grooming is a form of innocuous sensory activation. Innocuous sensory activation, characterized by non aggressive contact, stimulates an entirely separate neural pathway from nocuous aggressive sensory activation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uvnäs-Moberg|first=Kerstin|date=1997-01-01|title=Physiological and Endocrine Effects of Social Contact|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=807|issue=1|pages=146–163|doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.1997.tb51917.x|issn=1749-6632}}</ref> Innocuous sensations are transmitted through the dorsal column-medial lemniscal system.
=== Oxytocin === [[Oxytocin]] is a peptide hormone known to help express social emotions such as altruism, which in turn provides a positive feedback mechanism for social behaviours.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Kemp|first=Andrew H.|last2=Guastella|first2=Adam J.|date=2011-08-08|title=The Role of Oxytocin in Human Affect|journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science|language=en|volume=20|issue=4|pages=222–231|doi=10.1177/0963721411417547}}</ref> For example, studies in [[vampire bat]]s have shown that intranasal injections of oxytocin have increased the amount of allogrooming done by female bats.<ref name="Wilkinson1986" /> The release of oxytocin, found to be stimulated by positive touch( such as allogrooming), positive smells and sounds, can have physiological benefits to the individual. Benefits can include: relaxation, healing, and digestion stimulation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Uvnäs-Moberg|first=Kerstin|date=1998-11-01|title=OXYTOCIN MAY MEDIATE THE BENEFITS OF POSITIVE SOCIAL INTERACTION AND EMOTIONS1|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306453098000560|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|volume=23|issue=8|pages=819–835|doi=10.1016/S0306-4530(98)00056-0}}</ref> Further, reproductive benefits have been found such as studies in rats have shown that the release of oxytocin can increase male reproductive success. The role of oxytocin is important in maternal pair bonding, and is hypothesized to promote similar bonding in social groups as a result of positive feedback loops from social interactions.<ref name="Dunbar 260–268">{{Cite journal|last=Dunbar|first=R. I. M.|date=2010-02-01|title=The social role of touch in humans and primates: Behavioural function and neurobiological mechanisms|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0149763408001127|journal=Neuroscience & Biobehavioral Reviews|series=Touch, Temperature, Pain/Itch and Pleasure|volume=34|issue=2|pages=260–268|doi=10.1016/j.neubiorev.2008.07.001|pmid=18662717}}</ref>
=== Beta-endorphins === Grooming stimulates the release of [[beta-endorphin]], which is one physiological reason for why grooming appears to be relaxing.<ref name="Keverne1989">{{citation|title=Beta-endorphin concentrations in cerebrospinal fluid of monkeys are influenced by grooming relationships|year=1989|last1=Keverne|last2=Martensz|last3=Tuite|first1=E.B.|first2=N.D.|first3=B.|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|volume=14|issue=1–2|pages=155–161|doi=10.1016/0306-4530(89)90065-6|pmid=2525263}}</ref> Beta-endorphins are found in neurons in the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland. Beta-endorphins are found to be opioid agonists. Opioids are molecules that act on receptors to promote feelings of relaxation, and reduce pain.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Physiology and Pharmacology for Anesthesia: Foundations and Clinical Application: Expert Consult - Online and Print.|last=FRCA.|first=Hemmings, Hugh C., MD, PhD|date=2013-01-01|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-1437716795|oclc=830351627}}</ref> A study in monkeys shows the changes in opiate expression in the body, mirroring changes in beta-endorphin levels, influences desire for social grooming. In using [[Opioid receptor|opiate receptor]] blockades, which decrease the level of beta-endorphins, the monkeys responded with an increased desire to be groomed. In contrast, when the monkeys were given morphine, the desire to be groomed dropped significantly.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Keverne|first=Eric B.|last2=Martensz|first2=Nicholas D.|last3=Tuite|first3=Bernadette|date=1989-01-01|title=Beta-endorphin concentrations in cerebrospinal fluid of monkeys are influenced by grooming relationships|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0306453089900656|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|volume=14|issue=1–2|pages=155–161|doi=10.1016/0306-4530(89)90065-6|pmid=2525263}}</ref> Beta- endorphins have been difficult to measure in animal species, differently from oxytocin which can be measured by sampling cerebrospinal fluid, and therefore have not been linked as strongly with social behaviours.<ref name="Dunbar 260–268"/>
=== Glucocorticoids receptors === Glucocorticoids are steroid hormones that are synthesized in the adrenal cortex and are a part of the group of corticosteroids. Glucocorticoids are involved in immune function, and are a part of the feedback system that reduces inflammation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sapolsky|first=Robert M.|last2=Romero|first2=L. Michael|last3=Munck|first3=Allan U.|date=2000-02-01|title=How Do Glucocorticoids Influence Stress Responses? Integrating Permissive, Suppressive, Stimulatory, and Preparative Actions|url=https://academic.oup.com/edrv/article/21/1/55/2423840/How-Do-Glucocorticoids-Influence-Stress-Responses|journal=Endocrine Reviews|volume=21|issue=1|pages=55–89|doi=10.1210/edrv.21.1.0389|pmid=10696570|issn=0163-769X}}</ref> Further, glucocorticoids are involved in glucose metabolism. Studies in macaques have shown that increased social stress results in glucocorticoid resistance, further inhibiting immune function.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Capitanio|first=John P.|last2=Mendoza|first2=Sally P.|last3=Lerche|first3=Nicholas W.|last4=Mason|first4=William A.|date=1998-04-14|title=Social stress results in altered glucocorticoid regulation and shorter survival in simian acquired immune deficiency syndrome|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=95|issue=8|pages=4714–4719|issn=0027-8424|pmc=22556|pmid=9539804|doi=10.1073/pnas.95.8.4714}}</ref> Macaques who participated in social grooming showed decreased levels of viral load, which points toward decreased levels of social stress resulting in increased immune function and glucocorticoid sensitivity. Additionally, an article published in 1997 concluded that an increase in [[Maternal bond|maternal]] grooming resulted in a proportionate increase in [[Glucocorticoid receptor]]s on target tissue in the neonatal rat.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Dong|last2=Diorio|first2=Josie|last3=Tannenbaum|first3=Beth|last4=Caldji|first4=Christian|last5=Francis|first5=Darlene|last6=Freedman|first6=Alison|last7=Sharma|first7=Shakti|last8=Pearson|first8=Deborah|last9=Plotsky|first9=Paul M.|date=1997-09-12|title=Maternal Care, Hippocampal Glucocorticoid Receptors, and Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal Responses to Stress|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/277/5332/1659|journal=Science|language=en|volume=277|issue=5332|pages=1659–1662|doi=10.1126/science.277.5332.1659|issn=0036-8075|pmid=9287218}}</ref> In the study on neonatal rats, it was found that the receptor number was altered because of a change in both [[serotonin]] and [[thyroid-stimulating hormone]] concentrations. An increase in the number of receptors might influence the amount of [[negative feedback]] on corticosteroid secretion and prevent the undesirable side effects of an abnormal physiologic stress response.<ref>{{Citation|author=Sapolsky, Robert M.|authorlink=Robert Sapolsky|title=The Importance of a Well-Groomed Child|date=September 1997|journal=Science|volume=277|pages=1620–1621|doi=10.1126/science.277.5332.1620|pmid=9312858|issue=5332}}</ref> Social grooming can change the number of glucocorticoid receptors, which can result in increased immune function.
Studies have also shown that male baboons who participate more in social grooming show lower basal cortisol concentrations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ray|first=Justina C.|last2=Sapolsky|first2=Robert M.|date=1992-01-01|title=Styles of male social behavior and their endocrine correlates among high-ranking wild baboons|journal=American Journal of Primatology|language=en|volume=28|issue=4|pages=231–250|doi=10.1002/ajp.1350280402|issn=1098-2345}}</ref>

(1998)|title= Mutual grooming and preferred associate relationships in a band of free-ranging horses|journal= Applied Animal Behaviour Science|volume=59|issue=4|pages=265–276|doi=10.1016/S0168-1591(97)00129-9|year= 1998}} *{{cite journal|author=Wilkinson, G.S.|year=1986|title= Social grooming in the common vampire bat, ''Desmodus rotundus''|format=PDF|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=34|issue=6|pages=1880–1889|url=http://www.life.umd.edu/faculty/wilkinson/Wilk_AB86.pdf|doi=10.1016/S0003-3472(86)80274-3|citeseerx=10.1.1.539.5104}} *{{cite journal|authors=Keverne, E.B.; Martensz, N.D.; Tuite, B.|year=1989|title= Beta-endorphin concentrations in cerebrospinal fluid of monkeys are influenced by grooming relationships|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|volume=14|issue=1–2|pages=155–161|doi=10.1016/0306-4530(89)90065-6|pmid=2525263}} *{{cite journal|author=Sapolsky, Robert M.|date=September 1997|authorlink=Robert Sapolsky|title= The Importance of a Well-Groomed Child|journal=Science|volume= 277|issue=5332|pages=1620–1621|doi=10.1126/science.277.5332.1620|pmid=9312858}} *{{cite journal|authors=Vrontou, S.; Wong, A. revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Stayhealthy, Inc. | logo = File:Stayhealthy Logo 2012.svg| type = [[Private company|Private]]| foundation = 1995| location = [[Monrovia, California|Monrovia]], [[California]]| key_people = John Collins, CEO| industry = [[Healthcare]]| products = Stayhealthy® HealthCENTER Kiosk™ - Body Composition Analyzer - [http://www.rt6tracker.com RT6 Research Tracker] - Stayhealthy® Activity Monitor™ (SAM)| homepage = [http://www.stayhealthy.com www.stayhealthy.com] }}
'''Stayhealthy, Inc.''' is a privately held corporation that creates [[World Wide Web|web]]-enabled [[healthcare]] monitoring products. It was founded in the [[Dot-com bubble|dot-com]] era by [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] John Collins, and produces devices that monitor and measure such aspects of one's health like [[blood pressure]], [[heart rate]], [[body weight]], [[body mass index]], [[body composition]], body fat ([[adipose tissue]]), [[visual perception]], and [[calorie]]s burned.
The company's current products include: the Body Composition Analyzer which reads an individual’s body composition with no appreciable difference from hydrostatic weighing or the DXA scan;<ref>{{cite journal|last=Erceg|first=DN|title=The Stayhealthy bioelectrical impedance analyzer predicts body fat in children and adults.|display-authors=etal|pmid=20579521|doi=10.1016/j.nutres.2010.04.009|volume=30|journal=Nutr Res|pages=297–304}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bodyfatanalyzer.org/omron-body-fat-analyzer/|title=Omron Body Fat Analyzer|last=|first=|date=|work=|newspaper=Body Fat Analyzer|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-12|via=}}</ref> a HealthCENTER Kiosk which has numerous configurations (Body Composition, Blood Pressure, Weight, Hearing, and Vision); Research Activity Monitor; and the Stayhealthy Activity Monitor (SAM) calorie tracker.
In May 2011, [[Tommy Thompson]], former Secretary of the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services and Governor of Wisconsin, was elected to serve as Chairman of the Board.<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/former-hhs-secretary-tommy-g-thompson-to-chair-stayhealthy-board-121879158.html</ref>
The company has a deal with [[Albertsons]] to place kiosks in their stores.<ref>http://www.prweb.com/releases/2014/04/prweb11761935.htm</ref>
The company has a deal with [[SuperValu (United States)]] to place kiosks in their stores.<ref>http://drugstorenews.com/article/supervalu-now-features-stayhealthy-healthcenter-kiosks</ref>
The company has a deal with [[Kroger]] to place kiosks in their stores.<ref>http://bizbeatblog.dallasnews.com/tag/stayhealthy-inc/</ref>
On 13 March 2004, Stayhealthy sued [[AmerisourceBergen]].
In 2005, Stayhealthy unveiled the Fitness Expert product, a fusion of the Body Composition Analyzer and the Calorie Tracker, which was to be sold via [[multi-level marketing]] company [[Quixtar]]. This deal has since fallen through.
The company was acquired by [[higi]] in 2014 [http://www.mobihealthnews.com/35808/higi-and-stayhealthy-team-up-in-kiosk-consolidation].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.stayhealthy.com Stayhealthy.com] *[http://www.rt6tracker.com Stayhealthy RT6 Research Tracker]
[[Category:Companies based in Los Angeles County, California]]
{{med-company-stub}}

hr)
26300 (rat, 1 hr){{IDLH|79016|Trichloroethylene}} | LCLo = 2900 ppm (human)
37,200 ppm (guinea pig, 40 min)
